description: Animal-assisted  therapy (AAT) is an intervention that can be used with children or adults in which an animal that has met specific criteria is used as an integral part of therapy sessions.(1,2) AAT can be delivered and/or directed by a healthcare provider who has been trained in these techniques.(1) AAT is intended to promote improvement in a person’s physical, social, emotional, or cognitive functioning and can be provided in a variety of settings, including groups or individual sessions.(1,2) Trained animals who have met specific criteria can be taught to reinforce behaviors in human patients, such as throwing, walking, or verbally responding.(1) The specific goals of AAT are determined by the treating therapist based on a thorough evaluation.(2) Animals can be incorporated into the lives of patients and healthcare providers in other ways as well:

Animal-assisted  activities (AAAs) can be provided in a variety of settings by specially trained professionals, paraprofessionals, or volunteers and animals that have met certain standards (see guidelines below). The animal interactions are geared toward enhancing education, motivation, and recreation; however, these activities are not specifically therapeutic in nature(1,12)

Resident animals (RAs) live permanently in a facility (e.g., nursing home, assisted living facility, rehabilitation hospital). Care for the animals is provided by those in their home environment, including by staff, volunteers, and/or residents.(1) RAs can be included in facility activities and therapy schedules if they meet specific criteria (e.g., proper training, appropriate temperament).(1,12) They also might participate in general interactions with facility residents without a therapeutic plan(1) –RAs provide opportunities for residents to perform increased physical activity and ADLs through the care of animals (e.g., feeding, grooming, exercise) and can offer a sense of purpose, prompting better self-care(1)

Assistance animals are animals that are trained in order to be permanently placed with individuals with disabilities(3,25) –Service animals: physical disability(3) –Hearing animals: hearing impairment(3) –Guide animals: visual impairment/loss(3) –Companion animals: provide emotional and social support –Medical alert animals can help individuals with psychiatric impairment, seizures, diabetes, or other medical problems(3)
indications: AAT is indicated for a variety of functional impairments and/or underlying diagnoses. Interactions with animals can provide emotional and physical health  benefits for diverse human populations, including older adults, children and adults with developmental and/or acquired physical and/or cognitive disability, individuals with sensory impairments such as blindness and/or hearing loss, and patients with emotional, behavioral, or psychosocial disturbances(1)
reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this intervention
Occupational therapy sessions that include AAT can be billed to third-party  payers as long as sessions meet the guidelines for intervention(3)

The Joint Commission and CARF International (an independent, nonprofit accreditor of health and human services; formerly the Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities) both support the use of AAT in therapy as long as it is appropriate for the needs and goals of the individual patient(3) Indications for device/equipment
contraindications precautions to test: Occupational therapy evaluations should utilize a client-centered approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(4) –A client-centered  approach includes the following principles: -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about his or her occupational functioning(4) -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes(4)  -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent(4) -Evaluation and treatment should be patient-centered and focus on the patient’s culture, roles, and interests(4) -When the patient is able to define the problems that he or she would like to work on, the patient also becomes a problem solver(4) -The patient should evaluate his or her own performance and set personal goals(4)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review medical chart and physician reports to ascertain information regarding the patient’s diagnosis, medical treatments, and functional impairments. For what reason has the patient been referred for AAT?

course of treatment.medical management: Document medical management of underlying diagnosis to date
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Note the results of all diagnostic tests completed to date
Diagnostic imaging (e.g., MRI, CT scan, chest X-ray)
Blood work (e.g., CBC, platelets, PT/INR, PTT, BUN, creatinine, glucose, urinalysis)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient require mechanical ventilation? If so, why, what type, what are the settings? -Does the patient become short of breath? If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise? When exposed to animal dander? Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document previous history of the same or similar diagnoses and/or functional impairments; document previous use of AAT as well as whether the patient was successful in this type of therapy
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What are the patient’s daily occupations and role(s) within his or her family? -Is he or she currently employed? -Is the patient hoping to return to work? -What activities and hobbies did the patient enjoy prior to the onset of functional impairments? -Did the patient enjoy animals prior to onset of functional impairments? -Is the patient afraid of animals or a specific type of animal? This would be a contraindication for AAT(3) -For children with developmental disabilities and delays, is the child interested in animals? -A patient/caregiver interview is often helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community roles, interests, prior work status, and home responsibilities
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be used based on patient’s current level of functioning? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -Who is the patient’s primary caregiver? -With whom does the patient live (e.g., spouse/partner, parents, children, siblings, grandparents, caregivers)? Does the patient currently reside in a facility? -Are there pets in the home? -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; are any modifications necessary? -Inquire about the levels of the home, including stairs and number of floors

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI, as this might determine if patient is appropriate for AAT involving animal riding (e.g., horses, dolphins, elephants)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices –Animals can be used as assistive technology for individuals with disabilities(1)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate static and dynamic balance functionally during ADL tasks involving weight shifting –Tinetti Balance Scale(6) –Berg Balance Scale
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess heart rate, blood pressure, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity; use Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale if indicated -Authors of a meta-analysis  of the effects of AAT sessions on stress found that there were significant improvements in heart rate, self-reported  anxiety, and self-reported  stress after AAT sessions compared with prior to AAT(20) -Document any negative change in vital signs that occurs after an animal is introduced into the therapy session; fear of or discomfort around animals is a contraindication for AAT
Monitor breathing to assist with determining fatigue and endurance levels
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesAssess patient for involvement of cranial and peripheral nervesBed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activitiesa measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seating position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility(7)an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition(8)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted)  –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking –If the patient presents with impaired gait, referral to physical therapy is appropriateAssess joint integrity and mobility –Document presence of contracturesAssess fine and gross motor function of the upper extremities; describe the quality of movement –Observe manual dexterity; serial opposition or rapidly touching each finger to thumb in succession –Modified Ashworth Scale (mAS) -Used to assess tone and reflexes -Severity of spasticity can be graded on the mAS –Motor Assessment Scale -Assesses motor function; includes disability and impairment measures; assessments include those of arm and hand movements, tone, and mobility –Arm Motor Ability Test (AMAT) -Evaluates arm functional ability and quality of movement; 28 tasks including eating with a spoon, opening a jar, tying a shoelace, and using the telephone –Jebsen Test of Hand Functionwriting, turning over stacked index cards, simulated eating, moving empty and weighted cans, and picking up small objects –9-hole  peg test for fine motor control
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT on muscles with contractures or abnormal tone or on muscles with coordination issues –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally; note any differences between the two hands –Assess grip force in functional tasks –Assess pinch strength with pinch gauge
observation inspection palpation includi: Patients with open wounds are not good candidates for AAT(3)

Observe for and document presence of skin breakdown or scratches upon initial evaluation and at the start of each treatment session; report new or changing skin breakdown to patient’s nurse and/or physician •Perception (e.g., visual field, spatial relations)
Ocular motor screening includes tracking through all planes, visual accommodation, and clarity of vision
Document complaints of double vision, optic pain, or visual field cuts
Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  is appropriate if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document patient’s ability to communicate, level of arousal, memory, attention, problem solving, and orientation to person, place, time, and situation –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) as indicated and appropriate(5)

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients who need this intervention or those with a diagnosis for which this intervention is used may be at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols ›Diagnosis/need for device/equipment:  The OT must consider the patient’s risk factors and deficits to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for the use of AAT in occupational therapy

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to physical therapy if the patient has difficulty with gait, balance, or lower extremity strength deficits Referral to speech therapy if the patient presents with a speech, language, cognitive, or swallowing problem Referral to neuropsychology for significant cognitive impairment Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  for assessment and treatment of visual disturbances Referral to dietitian if the patient has any feeding or swallowing difficulties and may be at risk for malnutrition; patient may require nutritional supplements or supplemental feedings Referral to recreational or vocational therapist for returning to activities of leisure and employment Referral to audiology if the patient appears to have a hearing loss Referral to psychiatry, psychology, or social work if patient appears depressed or anxious, is having difficulty coping, and/ or might benefit from assistance with issues such as facility placement Refer patient to allergist if the patient develops new respiratory or sinus symptoms after beginning AAT
other considerations: AAT participants can occasionally become overly involved and possessive of the animals, resulting in an atmosphere of competition rather than social cooperation(1)
Patients sometimes perceive that an animal has rejected them (often due to unrealistic expectations of an animal’s behavior toward them), which can exacerbate low self-esteem(1)
Death of a therapy animal can generate intense feelings of grief and sometimes guilt in both patients and staff(1)
treatment summary: ROM –Petting or brushing an animal’s fur/hair(2) –Throwing a ball to be fetched by a dog(2) –Swinging a toy to be chased by a cat(2)

Muscle strength –Squeezing out a tube of something (e.g., topical cream, hairball remedy, food/treat) for an animal(2) –Milking a cow(2) –Brushing an animal’s fur or hair; can add weights to a brush to increase difficulty(2) –Scooping kitty litter into a litter box(2) –Lifting and carrying bags of pet food(2)
Hand contractures –Petting an animal with an open hand(2) –Attempting to feed an animal from an open hand(2) –Leaning on an opened hand while playing with an animal using the other hand(2)
Sensory processing –Petting soft animals, such as rabbits or hamsters(2) –Petting animals with different textured hair, fur, or skin(2)
Fine motor skills –Clipping on a leash and/or buckling a collar(2) –Retrieving a small treat from a container(2)
Mobility –Taking a dog for a walk(2)
Memory –Remembering to feed an animal according to a schedule; incorporating memory strategies and devices as needed(2) –Learning about and reporting on different breeds or types of animals(2)
Attention –Following directions related to animal care(2) –Answering questions about a specific animal’s characteristics(2) –Watching animals play or run for a specific amount of time(2)

Social skills –Taking turns petting or playing with an animal(2) –Discussing an animal or past experiences with animals with the OT or a peer(2) –Sharing tasks of caring for one animal with a partner(2) –Learning about treating an animal (and fellow human) with kindness and gentleness(2) –Engaging in social communication(11) -Authors of a pilot study, conducted in Canada, involving 3 female children with language impairment found that AAT used in a play-based  speech-language pathology setting appeared to facilitate increased sustained social interaction in 2 of the 3 girls

Self-care  skills –Participating in the proper care of an animal(2) –Grooming an animal(2) –Feeding an animal and providing water(2) –Dressing a dog in dog clothes that are appropriate for the weather(2) –Buying a treat at the pet store for the animal(2)
Self-esteem –Success in any of the abovementioned activities can promote increased self-esteem(2)

Authors of a pilot study in the United States suggested that AAT can be feasible in group therapy sessions and can be incorporated in a fitness program in order to engage older residents in physical activity(15)

Authors of an RCT conducted in Italy concluded that AAT positively affects global functioning and school attendance in children and adolescents with psychiatric disorders(14) –Thirty-four  participants between 11 and 17 years of age in whom an acute psychiatric disorder had been diagnosed were included in this study –Participants were equally divided into the treatment group (AAT group) or the control group –The treatment group received AAT intervention in structured sessions which were individualized to the recipient; AAT group treatments were performed weekly for 3–4 months –Significant improvements were noted in all outcome measures, which included global functioning, reduction in care, and increased school attendance

Authors of an RCT conducted in Korea suggest that caring for insects can be a low-cost  alternative to AAT that can reduce depression and have positive effects on cognitive function in community-dwelling older adults(16) –Based on an 8-week  study involving 94 older adults who were randomized to either the insect-caring  group (n = 46) or control group (n = 48) –The insect-caring  group were given the tasks of caring for 5 crickets in a cage with appropriate instructions on care and management –The insect-caring  group had lower scores on the Geriatric Depression Scale (GDS-15)  and improved scores on the MMSE compared to the control group

Authors of a study in Italy suggest that equine-assisted  therapy (EAT) can improve executive function and social function in children with ASD(17) –Twenty-eight  children with ASD (all males; ages 6–12) participated in this study –Sessions were held once per week for 6 months for 60–70 minutes per session (20 minutes of grooming; 10 minutes of hand-walking  the horse; 20–30  minutes of horseback riding; 10 minutes of closing session)

Incorporating dogs in OT treatment has been shown to improve communication, behavioral regulation, and participation in children and adolescents with ASD(22) –The presence of dogs facilitated engagement, enjoyment, and motivation to participate with therapy

In a similar study in which dogs were incorporated into a therapy program, improvements in social-communication behaviors were found in psychiatrically hospitalized youths with ASD. Participants in the interventiondisplayed positive emotional expressions, spoke more, and were able to maintain longer levels of eye contact with adults and peers(23)

Authors of a study conducted in Korea compared the effects of simulated horseback riding to real horseback riding and found that simulated horseback riding produced similar results in muscle activity of the trunk and thigh, suggesting that a simulated horseback experience can be an effective alternative to actual riding to improve postural control and balance(24) See Description , Indications of device/equipment , and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . improved balance in static and dynamic t: Functional assessment, Berg Balance Scale, Tinetti
increased participation in therapeutic t: FIM, Physical Self-Maintenance  Scale (PSMS), Assessment of Motor and Process Skills (AMPS), Kohlman Evaluation ofLiving Skills (KELS), Frenchay Activities Index, and Barthel Activities of Daily Living Index

outcomes of occupational therapy should: Reliable measurements can be obtained by comparing scores on specific tasks/tests taken from both the initial anddischarge evaluations, utilizing standardized tests whenever possible

maintenance or prevention: Gains achieved during the course of therapy can be maintained through continued practice of the activities performed in therapy as well as through additional interaction with animals
